docs.lead_paragraph: This week's news about CT scans offered the latest evidence of the problem with fee-for-service medicine. Radiation from the CT scans done just in the year 2007 will eventually cause 15,000 extra deaths, researchers reported in The Archives of Internal Medicine. And scan use continues to rise, so the death toll will probably grow. An editorial accompanying the research paper suggested that there appeared to be "significant overuse" of such scans.

headline.main: CT Scans and Health Care Reform

docs.abstract: The problem with fee-for-service medicine, in a nutshell.
docs.snippet: The problem with fee-for-service medicine, in a nutshell.

docs.lead_paragraph: South Orange is considering urging the state to pass a statute allowing college towns to impose an annual fee on students to help offset the cost of providing municipal services to them.

headline.main: Should Seton Hall Students Pay South Orange?

docs.abstract: South Orange will likely be urging the state to allow college towns to impose an annual fee on students to help offset the cost of providing municipal services to them, particularly for police and firefighters.
docs.snippet: South Orange will likely be urging the state to allow college towns to impose an annual fee on students to help offset the cost of providing municipal services to them, particularly for police and firefighters.

docs.lead_paragraph: "Ask an Expert" is a recurring feature on Bucks in which you'll have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

headline.main: Answers About Cobra Benefits and Subsidies: Part 1

docs.lead_paragraph: The question is inescapable: by going on national television and threatening to join Republicans to defeat President Obama's top domestic priority, did Senator Joseph I. Lieberman actually save the Democrats' big health care bill?
docs.abstract: The independent from Connecticut may have accomplished what Democratic leaders could not: party unity.
docs.snippet: The independent from Connecticut may have accomplished what Democratic leaders could not: party unity.
